repo.description: The most widely used Python to C compiler
repo.name: cython

body:
This is a proposal to address #2485.  As [suggested](https://github.com/cython/cython/issues/2485#issuecomment-1079691738) by @da-woods I'm simply bypassing the check for a "const object" _if_ we are in a `MemoryViewSliceTypeNode`.  It feels quite hacky, but the numerous tests I've added are happy with that approach.  Note that some of the new tests emit compiler warnings like
```
extension_type_nditer.c:7112:27: warning: incompatible pointer types assigning to 'struct __pyx_obj_21extension_type_nditer_A *' from 'PyObject *' (aka 'struct _object *') [-Wincompatible-pointer-types]
              *__pyx_t_21 = __pyx_t_1;
                          ^ ~~~~~~~~~
```
This is a known issue and tracked in #3993. Finally I'm wondering whether this change would be a candidate to go in 0.29.x instead of (only) master so that it could be picked up downstream soon.

FWIW my gut feeling is that a cleaner way to get 'const object[:]` to work is...
1. Let `MemoryViewSliceTypeNode` have a const attribute
2. Let the parser attach the `const` qualifier in `const object[:] a` _not_ to the base type node, but to the memoryview node.

I tried to go that route, too, but my unfamiliarity with such internals let me become overwhelmed quite quickly.

comment_data.body: Could you use a local view instead of the global one here? Changing the global NumPy array may lead to unrelated test failures when the getter tests happen to run after the setter tests.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -34,3 +34,25 @@ def test_getitem_typed():
     for i in range(view.shape[0]):
         item = view[i]
         print item.dummy
+
+def test_setitem():
+    """
+    >>> test_setitem()
+    10
+    11
+    """
+    for i in range(view.shape[0]):
+        view[i] = ExtensionType(10+i)
+        print view[i].dummy

comment_data.body: I don't think the way `const` is handled for memory views is wrong. It means that the item data type is not writeable, which is correct. Think of structs, for example, where it's not just the memory view items but also the struct fields that must not be modified. Really, you could argue that there is no such thing as a `const object[:]`.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -1147,7 +1147,17 @@ class MemoryViewSliceTypeNode(CBaseTypeNode):
 
     def analyse(self, env, could_be_name=False):
 
-        base_type = self.base_type_node.analyse(env)
+        if isinstance(self.base_type_node, CConstOrVolatileTypeNode):
+            # In this tree the 'const' qualifier of this memoryview is attached
+            # to the node of the base type, but its meaning is
+            # 'const memoryview'.  For non-PyObject types this doesn't make a

comment_data.body:
Yes I agree that one can take this view.  For the use case I have in mind (see https://github.com/cython/cython/issues/2485#issuecomment-1079660938) though, the ultimate goal is to appease the numpy.nditer interpretation of the 'readonly' operand flag:  The operand ndarray is not written to, viz., no references in it are overwritten.  It doesn't make any assumptions on whether or not the referred to object changes.

Put differently:  Currently it is possible to appease the nditer/object ndarray/readonly combination by declaring the loop buffer through the legacy interface `cdef ndarray[object]`, but there is no way to achieve this with an `cdef object[:]` memoryview.  The proposed change is simply the most canonical solution from my perspective, and I would be happy with any other solution that would allow me to avoid the legacy API. (Without changing the 'readonly' flag to 'readwrite'.)
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -1147,7 +1147,17 @@ class MemoryViewSliceTypeNode(CBaseTypeNode):
 
     def analyse(self, env, could_be_name=False):
 
-        base_type = self.base_type_node.analyse(env)
+        if isinstance(self.base_type_node, CConstOrVolatileTypeNode):
+            # In this tree the 'const' qualifier of this memoryview is attached
+            # to the node of the base type, but its meaning is
+            # 'const memoryview'.  For non-PyObject types this doesn't make a

comment_data.body: Thanks, I have made all data and views local to the individual test functions.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -34,3 +34,25 @@ def test_getitem_typed():
     for i in range(view.shape[0]):
         item = view[i]
         print item.dummy
+
+def test_setitem():
+    """
+    >>> test_setitem()
+    10
+    11
+    """
+    for i in range(view.shape[0]):
+        view[i] = ExtensionType(10+i)
+        print view[i].dummy

commit.message: Basic tests for const object memoryview (GH-2485)
More tests for memoryviews on ndarrays of extension types (GH-2485)
Integration tests for memoryviews on object ndarrays (GH-2485)
Integration test for const memoryview with nditer (GH-2485)

Change 'const object[:]' semantics (GH-2485)

Instead of reading this as a memoryview of 'const object', we read
it now as 'read-only memoryview of type object', i.e., references
cannot be overwritten.

repo.description: The most widely used Python to C compiler
repo.name: cython

title: Allow const qualifier for memoryview on objects
